text: Let's start with the hot take. The perfect options trade is not about whether or not the trade itself makes money. I know. Actually, the annoying part here is some of the worst possible trades make money. So what is the perfect options trade? That's what we're going to talk about. So the thing to keep in mind is a good trade is not about luck. It's about precision. It's about timing. And we're going to talk about those two concepts along with how we structure a trade. What's up, everyone? Eric here. Welcome back to the outliers. Let's get right in. So we're going to talk about a few principles. Then I'm going to go through this thing. I call the big four trade process. And then I'm going to walk you through specific decisions that have to be made in order to ensure the perfect options trade is placed. So the very first principle I'm going to introduce you to is this idea of stacking strength. When we're looking for trades, it's common for us to see something that looks generally appealing and then to immediately try to figure out how to put a trade on in it. Let's take a look at an example. If we pop over to the platform, pop into a scan, let's take a look at this LIN. I'm looking for stocks that are near 52 week highs. That's all. And let's say we want to trade a bullish thesis for whatever reason.

And let's say we want to trade a bullish thesis for whatever reason. Do I like this for a bullish thesis? Well, if I look across the six month time frame, it's going up. That looks OK. And then if I look in on a three month time frame, it's going generally up. That's also OK. And if I look in on a 30 day, it starts to flatten out a little bit. Some of this is going to have to align with your timing, your trading window that you're pursuing. Well, let's take a look at something in comparison like XLC. If I want to trade something to the upside, this looks OK. It's definitely moving up. It doesn't have that big pullback like you're seeing in the LIN stock that we were just looking at. What I'm highlighting is we have to come up with multiple factors. So the idea of stacking strength is to look at multiple factors all together in conjunction, but not looking at one specific element and making a decision off of that one element. So the work in trading is done in building a plan that you trust. That's where all the rigor goes. So if we have a plan that we trust and we understand that we're not so concerned about the outcome of any one individual trade because we trust the plan and over time it leads to profitable results, then it's easier to focus on this key principle of focusing on making sure that we're putting on trades that align with our plan and are not over emphasizing the outcome of any one individual trade. I find a lot of traders are trying to find an excuse. Something is in this steep, sharp decline and they're like, well, it might turn around. I want to get in now or it might go lower. Who really knows? But the idea of trying to build a trade premise off of essentially confirmation bias, trying to see the things that you want to see for something to go up is a terrible, terrible habit. So I flip that on its head and I look for reasons to say no. And if there are too many reasons that lead me or that lead to no, then it's no trade. That's simple. Let's talk about the big four trade process. This is in a couple different videos, so I'm going to gloss over this quickly. But when we're placing the perfect options trade in my opinion, it follows this exact process. We're going to start by assessing portfolio fit. Is this something? Are we looking for something that fits a specific need for our portfolio? Do we need long delta, short delta, is do we need theta? Do we need more gamma? Whatever it is?
